topic.title: What is the difference between a rapist and a voter?
topic.body: Yes, it's a hyperbolic question, but I'm genuinely interested to know what YOU think.

1516184122_1J6csQA9K9NZaYUiCG5C2XQRF85yB.body:
Hi, 

I have read: http://zeronet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/faq/#how-can-i-register-a-bit-domain
but so far I'm unable to display the site through it's .bit address.

I have a ZeroNet site: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1C1hKsqjQTR1iy1ijB3qtrqBwfH2Hf7TMW/ I bought a .bit domain: squashpassionapps.bit which is verified at: https://namecha.in/name/d/squashpassionapps

Is the namecoin domain 'pointing' to the zeronet address because the 'value' is the the Bitcoin address generated by zeronet (1C1hKsqjQTR1iy1ijB3qtrqBwfH2Hf7TMW)?

If so it's not working when I type "http://squashpassionapps.bit/" or "http://127.0.0.1:43110/squashpassionapps.bit/" into the browser  (http://127.0.0.1:43110/1C1hKsqjQTR1iy1ijB3qtrqBwfH2Hf7TMW/ still works fine).

Update: I've added the following to the data field: {"ip":"<my IP>", "map": {"*": {"ip":"<my IP>"}}} "zeronet": { "1C1hKsqjQTR1iy1ijB3qtrqBwfH2Hf7TMW": "1EU1tbG9oC1A8jz2ouVwGZyQ5asrNsE4Vr", "blog": "1BLogC9LN4oPDcruNz3qo1ysa133E9AGg8", "talk": "1TaLk3zM7ZRskJvrh3ZNCDVGXvkJusPKQ" }

Is this correct? Is there more I should add? I'm on win 7 and have avoided the CLI so far and would prefer to work just from the GUI, which should be possible if it is to achieve wider adoption.

Currently the Chrome browser just reports:
Not Found
/squashpassionapps.bit

What have I missed?/Should be looking at?

Thanks for any help ...

Update: I used the simple format in the 'value' field of 'manage names' in namecoin-qt:
{"zeronet": { "": "1GW6cZopqosRPfRs8sws9P8nAjorEQGo4C"}}
and finally got my .bit address working through my browser (only once the block countdown had started in namecoin-qt).
The documentation (referring to sub-domains etc., although useful in for more advanced use) was misleading. Simple as possible (as above) first is best to get up and running initially.

1516732205_18cuVo4ak3NDVwhTCXE5WtUc4q5ZX.body: I got from WEX a couple of days ago - no problems ...

1526455814_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6n.body: I've created some original content (a site). Is there any way I can be identified as the original creator of that content? I know it can be copied and 'improved' upon, which is fine. The site has a 'donation' page for anyone who may appreciate the original content. Presumably there's nothing to prevent someone simply changing the donation crypto references and re-publishing the site as their own? Do I need to make it a 'private' site?

> [marketforce](#comment_23_1ENvPHLeuUKJAWsup9tL9C1mdZeb1ycjp8): As was said, there's nothing that can prevent others from republishing. But I guess you could digitally sign the hash of your content with your site's private key and publish the hash and the signature here. Then if somebody copies the content there would be a proof in everyone's zeronet database that you were the first to publish it.

Thanks guys for the responses. I will try to digitally sign which might be best of both worlds. Ability to claim original ownership whilst enabling anyone to improve according to their own requirements.

Isn't the  hash of the content of the two main files (in content.json) already generated from the site's private key in users.json? The signature is the public key address of the site. So I post that and the hash of the two main content files here and I should be good to go? Which makes me consider if there could perhaps be some kind of 'original content' register linking relevant content hashes with ZeroID?

Thanks for the info. For the sake of clarity, this is my understanding: I can sign the site with any message I like. The signature (generated with the private key) will be cryptographically related to both the message and the site's address (public key) proving that only I (owner of private key) could have created that signature relating to that message. If challenged I could send a message to the challenger relating to the same address (public key) and another signature (which would be different if the message is different),  again proving my ownership. In other words because of my ownership of the private key only I can relate messages to the site address (public key)/signatures.

> [homulilly](#comment_72_1JXekkVYJNdozXPFXZEA1AJXKjkWyFciTD): Libertarians are fucking stupid, man

Asinine. Care to elaborate?

> [homulilly](#comment_80_1JXekkVYJNdozXPFXZEA1AJXKjkWyFciTD): Huh, interesting. Insanely fucked up he got life in prison then.

It's Libertarians (and Agorists) who are most consistently and vehemently opposed to this kind of State activity against free market places.

> [homulilly](#comment_81_1JXekkVYJNdozXPFXZEA1AJXKjkWyFciTD): They should be more focused on prison reform.

I suggest they're correctly focused on the absurdity of the idea that a market place should be outlawed and that imprisonment for free trade is legitimate. The actual conditions of imprisonment are almost completely irrelevant to that debate. If you think prison reform is more important you're a Reformist. Why should a Libertarian focus on something that has very little to do with Libertarian-ism?

1541600740_1P4KkC3wa5xtGD8m2MoBTf5p69G3X.body: Disliking child abuse isn't a reason to dislike ZeroNet. Child abuse is a manifestation of one person's Will being imposed without consent upon another (a foundational concept of our Society); ZeroNet is a manifestation of free speech, something that is essential to limiting the ability of the powerful to impose their Will upon the weak. You're disliking (a part of) the remedy because you dislike the symptoms of the disease, which, I suggest, is neither moral nor rational.

> [moor](#comment_41_17zoTjVZEBUdo6uAvQvtbih7ibBMHQRsrH): back up a little bit, symptom/disease was just an analogy, but you can't conclude from it. either way i think you are wrong,  (the act of) disliking may be subjective but it can essentially be objective and thus either rational or moral. [...]
What do you consider to be "the actual consequence of the nature of ZeroNet"?

> [moor](#comment_43_17zoTjVZEBUdo6uAvQvtbih7ibBMHQRsrH): exactly what you said, "ZeroNet is a manifestation of free speech", by being as such it defines the problems implied in it, free speech can take many forms, these forms, whatever they may be, are the consequence of 0Net nature.

If free speech takes the form of ZeroNet, am I wrong to say "Disliking child abuse isn't a reason to dislike ZeroNet"?

> [moor](#comment_44_17zoTjVZEBUdo6uAvQvtbih7ibBMHQRsrH): that wasn't my problem with your statement, but only the part that I've highlighted, which was your analogy.i agree with what you've said and the use of the analogy "You're disliking (a part of) the remedy because you dislike the symptoms of the disease" but you conclude from the analogy "which, I suggest, is neither moral nor rational". [...]

Thanks for your point. I will consider the issues under [Argument from analogy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_from_analogy) and how they relate.

> [peterme](#comment_1_1MbDT6wKmPFovbPV6q7E5LDN3GeYWiiNNW): what about deriving the moral from http://www.un.org/en/charter-united-nations/ ?I would propagate that und would be glad if i find followers here.

Does centralizing power lead to moral outcomes? for e.g. [Is the EU's recent pronouncement on free speech moral?](https://www.nationalreview.com/2018/10/free-speech-sharia-european-court-of-human-rights-ruling/)

> [ornataweaver](#comment_49_139zVkd4AsZqs9qSYk6ypPDAqDcjPCmRm4): What I truly dislike, is seemingly selfless people expecting you to be selfless for them.It's a twisted and sick kind of selfishness.

Agree. Writing this immorality into law in the form of taxation (extortion) is it's visible manifestation.

1555707064_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92T.body: Listen to [Hazlett - Economics In One Lesson](https://youtu.be/L6Lw-QAHzk4) to understand why this would be repeating old mistakes and making things worse. Don't vote. Ignore politicians.

> [adotham](#comment_9_1P8TFEmsFJruqWErsBLpTxmpczHFW3raWF): Right, because the best way to make yourself heard is to stop speaking

Politicians speak to coerce with violence. Can you only speak through them?

[David Friedman](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bpn645huKUg) encourages us to consider a system in which we can put our money where our mouth is and remove the need for politicians as they are conceived of today. Real change comes from ideas, which is why there's a concerted worldwide effort to censor. Don't let them divide and conquer. Give everyone the ability to choose economically rather than through 'rationally ignorant' voting.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_229_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): I  suspect a solution such as this would require a revolution, and my experience with the US is one of widespread apathy. Revolution doesn't seem likely. I think incremental change perhaps through rationally ignorant voting will get more done in the short term.

Slavery wasn't abolished incrementally.  For a good reason. It's wrong in principle. So is [voting](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hdKmkg6GVDU)

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_38_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): "Slavery wasn't abolished incrementally. For a good reason. It's wrong in principle."Obviously [...]

Learn to listen. Watch the video before replying. Yes, voting is a tool, but who is really wielding it?
What they didn't realize is that giving the slaves 'freedom' [wouldn't make any real difference](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vb8Rj5xkDPk).

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_39_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): "Yes, voting is a tool, but who is really wielding it?"Those who vote, hence the interest of voting, [...]

Those who vote gave us Clinton, Bush, Obama, Trump - all freedom haters.They delude themselves as they fall into the trap. But far more importantly they delude the underlings who do the dirty work into believing they have the Right to use violent coercion to impose their will on others. Many have seen it for what it is and hence there is often little interest in voting in the political sphere. The 'interest' only grows among those who don't really understand what they're doing - which is why they're encouraged to do it ... Even Adam Kokesh 'Not For President' doesn't work.

What's wrong with anarchy?

[...]

Voting is not playing it 'smart'. Look around. You seem rather obsessed with Freemasons. Like politicians (of whom many are Freemasons) I suggest simply ignoring them and building your own systems of collaboration and commerce. Let them slide into irrelevance ...

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_46_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): Because I like it and there is no prison. Isn't that a great model ?

You would like to kill me? You don't even know me ... There may be a prison ... It depends on whatever arrangements I have with my preferred [Rights Enforcement Agency](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jTYkdEU_B4o).

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_47_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): You should be obsessed with the Masonic Perspective but like most people you are far too wrapped up in your filthy ignorance to understand how this world really works. Don't worry, they've got you warm in the palm of their hand. [...]

Where will you be?

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_48_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): Anarchy means no prison, now you want a prison, so it's no longer anarchy kiddo;it's order. [...]

How are you defining anarchy?

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_49_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): Where do you want me to be, looney,you choose your neighbors ?

Where do I want you to be? Getting an education somewhere ... i don't wish to be rude, but you did ask ...

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_50_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): lol. You're talking about anarchy and you don't even know what anarchy is. You're here for a salon chat, you need cupcakes with your tea?

That's not an answer. Can you answer the question?

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_54_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): Everything I learned I learned by myself, I never waited for the answer.If you expect something from me, you're not going to be served. [...]

I didn't think so ...

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_55_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): WHO CARES. lol. Not Me.You are trying to establish a dialogue to brighten up 'your dull life'. If you're not aware yet, sitting behind a computer is NOT EXACTLY LIFE.Ah these young generations and their virtual worlds; they shop online, they fuck online, and think that a chat IS AN EXCHANGE BEWTEEN PEOPLE. These generations are so lost.

It's clear who is lost  ...

> [gametangia](#comment_18_193rzuH9AAHfvHKwSFS5oq6jRpXwDJ2rEW): That is true, nations don't account for external costs, businesses and customers do. And I already gave a pretty fair example of how environmental costs are handled in a free society. People want clean air, people want clean water, people don't want mercury and coal dust dumped in their back yards, and if you privatize these costs with DROs, then suddenly you have people spending money on protecting the environment, and that money is invested in R&D and infrastructure to limit environmental damages; and the companies with the best R&D divisions sell the best technology to other firms and so on.I don't know what you do for a living, I don't want to make any presuppositions, but I do think that people who don't work natural resource management have been painted an inaccurate picture of how procurement companies function. I manage forests and timber/fiber plantations, and here in the southeastern United States, 95% of forested land is privately owned, it is productive, well kept, and sustainably managed because people harvest the wood on it. You hire timber cruisers to assess the property, some trees are taken for lumber, others are left to regrow the forest. Meanwhile the government managed land out west is Hell--theirs is used more for grazing than forestry of course but compare the value of an acre of government land set aside for ranchers to graze cattle on to an acre of privately managed land, it's night and day. [...]

Thanks for a response which demonstrates you actually know what you're talking about. One of the problems of our current electoral system is that your opinion on this topic only carries as much weight as the next brainwashed group-thinker. It's not granular so that those in the know get to determine how an industry e.g. timber, is properly managed. Instead people look for one 'dear leader' who can take all the responsibility and do all the thinking for them (and end up just telling the ignorant what they want to hear). The best way I'm aware of to make that transition is to abandon traditional politics as we know it altogether and allow our spending to do the 'talking'. If some of the contributors here had to put their money where their mouth is, it wouldn't be long before they had very little currency left to do any damage with their shallow and irrelevant thinking. This is Agorism.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_267_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): I fail to see how America's leadership could get worse than Trump and his policies.

It always gets worse as each new administration bloats the bureaucracy of the State, trampling freedom as it goes.

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_102_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): We must train generations and generations of LEADERS WITH VALUES, there are no miracles. no leaders=no defenders of values.= destruction of society From Within.

So you want someone else to make all the tough decisions on your behalf? The search for 'leaders' is the problem. Use your own judgement.

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_108_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): One example I did in the army, there were people I hated, but I also saw people who made me realize that I could follow THEM BECAUSE THEY 'WERE VALUABLE'. [...]

They must have resonated with your existing value system for you to perceive them as valuable. It came from you, not them. You don't need to be in the army to recognize people you value and to decide for yourself if you will follow them (e.g. perhaps your boss at work). In the army you must follow the people you hate as well as the people you value. Sacrificing who you are and your value system for the supposed 'greater good' is a tragic loss to humanity, of your humanity.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_269_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): Aside from the obvious political persuasions of China in general, all I see is  a man with a committee overseeing the removal of corrupt officials from positions of power in the Chinese government. Xi Jinpings doesn't appear to me to be anything but a good influence on the governmental structure.

Our media is managed, as it always has been, so that we see enormous concentrations of power in the hands of single individuals as a positive development. Even if he is a 'good influence' (I'm in no position to determine), if you're a good influence on a bad entity, is that a good thing?

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_272_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): Bad systems (entities) don't get better without good influences. The fundamental structure of the US political system is not likely to change quickly. Why perpetuate the agenda of the bad system by electing people who are likely to perpetuate it?

Indeed, that's why I'm suggesting not electing anyone. Ignore them all and encourage them, and everyone else who never considered the idea, to understand that their perceived 'authority' is a dangerous delusion.
